review.title: Probabilistic Relational Model Benchmark Generation
review.abstract: The validation of any database mining methodology goes through an evaluation process where benchmarks availability is essential. In this paper, we aim to randomly generate relational database benchmarks that allow to check probabilistic dependencies among the attributes. We are particularly interested in Probabilistic Relational Models (PRMs), which extend Bayesian Networks (BNs) to a relational data mining context and enable effective and robust reasoning over relational data. Even though a panoply of works have focused, separately , on the generation of random Bayesian networks and relational databases, no work has been identified for PRMs on that track. This paper provides an algorithmic approach for generating random PRMs from scratch to fill this gap. The proposed method allows to generate PRMs as well as synthetic relational data from a randomly generated relational schema and a random set of probabilistic dependencies. This can be of interest not only for machine learning researchers to evaluate their proposals in a common framework, but also for databases designers to evaluate the effectiveness of the components of a database management system.

metadata.title: Probabilistic Relational Model Benchmark Generation

sections.text: Keywords: Probabilistic Relationship Model, Relational Data Representation, Benchmark Generation

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is a very complex matter, a political project, which is first and foremost a political project.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: This section first provides a brief review of Bayesian networks and relationship models and then introduces PRMs.

sections.heading: 2.1 Bayesian networks
sections.text: Bayesian networks (BNs) [27] are directed acyclic graphs allow to efficient encode and manipulation probability distributions over high-dimensional spaces. Formally, they are defined as: Definition 1 A Bayesian network B = < G, ы > is defined by: 1) A graphical component (structure): a directed acyclic graph (DAG) G = (V, E), where V is the set of versed random variables A = {A1,.. An, and E is the set of directed edands corresponding to conditional dependence relations between these variables.2) A numerical component (parameters) that is the set of n discrete random variables A = {A1,.., and E is the set of directed edants corresponded dependence relations between the conditional dependence relations between the variables.2) A numerical component (parameters) is the set of distributed n discrete random variables A = A1, A1.

sections.heading: 2.2 Relational model
sections.text: The way the data is stored in a database depends on the way it is stored in a database.

sections.heading: 2.3 Probabilistic relational models
sections.text: It is not only a question of relationship, but also a question of behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour, behaviour and behaviour.

sections.heading: 3 PRM Benchmark Generation
sections.text: Due to the lack of known PRMs in the literature, this paper proposes a synthetic approach to randomly generate probabilistic relationship models, randomly instantiate them, and fill relational databases.

sections.heading: 3.1 Principle
sections.text: Because we work with a relational diversity of Bayesian networks, our generation process is inspired by classical methods of generating random BNs, respecting the relational domain representation.The overall process is outlined in Algorithm 1. The proposed generation process is roughly divided into three main steps: • The first step generates a random PRM by generating a relational schema using the Generate CPD function (Section 3.2), and then generating a graph dependency structure using Generate Dependency Structure and Determinine Slot Chains Functions (Section 3.3). Finally, conditional probability tables are generated using the Generate CPD function in the same way as Bayesian networks (see Section 2.1). • The second step illustrates the model generated in the first step.

sections.heading: 3.2 Generation of a random relational schema
sections.text: Our goal is to generate a relationship scheme with a certain number of classes, so that it does not contain reference cycles and also respects the definition of the relationship model in Section 2.2. We apply concepts from graph theory to the creation of random schemes. We associate this problem with a process of generating DAG keys, where nodes represent relationships and edges are reference constraints. Xi → Xj means that Xi is the reference relationship and Xj is the referenced one. We also strive to construct schemes where Xi, Xi and Xi have a reference path between the keys. This assumption makes it possible to search through all classes to discover probable dependencies later, and it is constructed by searching for DAG attributes that contain a single contiguous component (i.e., contiguous key indicators).

sections.heading: 3.3 Generation of a random PRM
sections.text: We must randomly generate probable dependencies between the attributes of the classes in the schema. These dependencies must provide the DAG of the dependency structure S and a set of CPDs that define a PRM (cf. Definition 3).We focus in particular on the random generation of the dependency structure. Once it is identified, conditional probability distributions can similarly be scanned as standard BNs parameter generation.The dependency structure S should be a DAG to guarantee that each generated ground network is also a DAG [14]. S has the specificity that one descriptive attribute can be linked to another, with various possible slots chains. Theoretically, the number of slots chains can be infinite. In practice, a user-defined maximum slot length Dmax should be specified to identify the horizon of all possible slots chains.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Constructing the DAG structure
sections.text: The idea here is to find for each node X.A a group of parents from the same class or from other classes, promoting class-internal dependencies in order to control the complexity of the final model discussed in [14]. This condition promotes the discovery of dependencies within the class or dependencies from short class-specific chains. The longer the slot chain is, the lower the chance of finding a probable dependency by the slot chain. To follow this condition, we propose to construct dependencies within the classes, each of which is built by attributes of the corresponding class.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Determining slot chains
sections.text: During this step, we must bear in mind that a variable can be reached by different slot chains and that the dependence between two descriptive attributes depends on the attribute selected. [14] Following, the process of creating shorter slot chains must be given more priority for selection. Consequently, we have used the term of punishment discussed in [14]. Longer indirect slot chains are punished by applying the probability of occurrence of a probable − slot chain list (Pot Slot Chains List), which is inversely proportional to exploration. A dependency X.A → Y.B between two descriptive attributes X.A and Y.B, we begin by generating the list of all possible slot chains (Pot Slot Chains List) of the length from which X Y can be reached in the relation scheme using the Potential Slot Chains.

sections.heading: 3.4 GBN generation
sections.text: The generated scheme, together with the added probable dependencies and generated parameters, results in a probable relationship model. To instantiate this latter, we must imagine a relational skeleton in which there are objects of different classes that are referenced in the associated relational scheme and edges from one object to another that already exists at the meta-level. Indeed, this graph is a special case of k-partite graphs, the graph graph graph graph of the definition Graph 8 of the definition Graph 6 of the relation chain as a special case of k-partite classes is a special case of k-partite graphs, Gk = (Vk, Ek), with the following properties: 1. The graph is acyclic, 8A-partite Graph is a graph whose relational chain can be placed in a special case of k-partition graphs with the following properties:

sections.heading: 3.5 Database population
sections.text: This process is comparable to generating data from a Bayesian network. We can create as many relational database instances as necessary by scanning from the constructed GBN. What is special about the generated tuples is that they are scanned not only from functional dependencies, but also from probable dependencies of the randomly generated PRM.

sections.heading: 4 Toy example
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 5 Implementation
sections.text: This section explains the implementation strategy of our generator, identifies the policies chosen and discusses the complexity of the algorithms.

sections.heading: 5.1 Software implementation
sections.text: The proposed algorithms were implemented in the PILGRIM10 API, a software platform that our laboratory is actively developing to provide an efficient tool for handling multiple probable graphical models (e.g. BNs, Dynamic BNs, PRMs). Developed in C + +, PILGRIM Boost uses graph library 11 to manage graphs, ProBT API12 to manipulate BNs objects, and Database Template Library (DTL) 13 to communicate with databases. Currently, only PostgreSQL RDBMS is supported on this platform. In addition to the algorithms, we have also implemented serialization of PRMs. As there is currently no formalization of PRMs, we propose an improved version of the XML syntax of the ProbModelXML specification 14 to serialize our generated models.

sections.heading: 5.2 Implemented policies
sections.text: To generate the relationship schema DAG structure randomly, we use a PMMixed algorithm (see Section 2.1) that generates uniformly distributed DAGs in DAGs space. To obtain this condition along with the interest in generating a uniformly distributed DAG structure, we can use a separate graph, whereas we need a DAG structure that contains only one contiguous component. To obtain this condition, along with the interest in generating a uniformly distributed DAG structure, we follow the rejection technique.The idea is to generate a DAG according to the PMMixed principle, if this DAG contains only one contiguous component, then it is accepted, otherwise it is rejected. We repeat these steps until we generate a DAG structure that meets our condition.Guidelines for generating attributes and their cardinalities. After we have the graphical structure, we proceed by defining for each relationship a R, we define a series of attributes − A where we create a PMA (a series of attributes − A).

sections.heading: 5.3 Complexity of the generation process
sections.text: We have reported this work at this stage because it is closely related to the choice of implementation guidelines. Let N be the number of relationships (classes), we report on the average complexity of each step of the generation process. Complexity of the process of generating the relational schema. Algorithm 2 is structured of three loops, the most expensive being the first loop designated for the DAG structure and using the PMMixed algorithm. The time complexity of the PMMixed algorithm is O (N-lgN), which is called until the stop state (i.e., a connected DAG) is reached. Let T be the average number of calls of the PMMixed algorithm. T is the ratio of the number of all connected DAG attributes from N nodes [31] to the number of all DAGs constructed from N nodes [3]. The time complexity of the algorithm is class 2-N (T-O).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and perspectives
sections.text: We have developed a method that allows random probability models to be generated and instantiated to fill a relational database. Generated relational data is sampled not only from the functional dependencies of the relationship scheme, but also from the probability dependencies present in PRM. Our method can generally be used by other data mining methods as a probabilistic generative model that allows randomly generated relational data to be generated. Furthermore, it can be enriched with test query components to help database designers evaluate the effectiveness of their RDBMS components.

metadata.abstractText: The validation of any database mining methodology goes through an evaluation process where benchmarks availability is essential. In this paper, we aim to randomly generate relational database benchmarks that allow to check probabilistic dependencies among the attributes. We are particularly interested in Probabilistic Relational Models (PRMs), which extend Bayesian Networks (BNs) to a relational data mining context and enable effective and robust reasoning over relational data. Even though a panoply of works have focused, separately, on the generation of random Bayesian networks and relational databases, no work has been identified for PRMs on that track. This paper provides an algorithmic approach for generating random PRMs from scratch to fill this gap. The proposed method allows to generate PRMs as well as synthetic relational data from a randomly generated relational schema and a random set of probabilistic dependencies. This can be of interest not only for machine learning researchers to evaluate their proposals in a common framework, but also for databases designers to evaluate the effectiveness of the components of a database management system.
